data.title: Tab DnD sometimes gets the wrong editor group as destination
data.body:
#7854

2. Drag a tab from a second to the top level group actions of that group
3. Tab misetiously shows up in the first editor group

data.title: Screen cheese when close all to the right
data.body:
#7854
- VSCode Version: insiders
- OS Version: os x

Steps to Reproduce:

In the second editor group:
1.  open two tabs
2.  open two / three more untitled tabs by double clicking on margin
3. second tab context menu -> close all to the right
4. I get screen cheese

Please try a couple of times since I do not repro this 100% but happens every other time..

data.title: font-weight 300 on Mac for italic font styles
data.body: This fixes issues around showing preview editors.

data.title: Tab color refinements
data.body: Fixes #7649 You'll notice that this variation of the tabs has a horizontal bar under the entire title and that only the active tab is shown boxed. It also is a darker color, matching the viewlet color. This line and the darker color combined help differentiate the find/replace widget. Also, consequently this is a simplification of what we have already. Before (3 colors and boxy-looking) After (2 colors and more flat) Also introduces `mix-blend-mode` to make tabs very responsive to themes #8151.

data.title: When terminal is focused, selecting test in editor won't focus the editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open terminal 
2. Open a text editor as well
3. Execute a command in terminal 
4. Using mouse make a selection in editor 

Editor is not focused. You have to click on editor again to focus in it

data.title: Git not installed, even when it's installed (NOT DUPLICATE)
data.body:
Okay, this might be the worst bug report ever, because I'm completely new to Microsoft technologies, I'll try my best to keep it accurate and easy for you guys :)
- VSCode Version: Don't know, today I clicked on download and it downloaded me a file vscode-amd64.deb without version number on file (maybe should start version numbers on files) I went back to that site, then I couldn't find anything on versions.
- OS Version: Well, I'm running Manjaro and my `uname -r` gives me `4.1.26-1-MANJARO` which is a arch linux based OS

Description:
I tried to `sudo dpkg -i vscode-amd64.deb` and it resulted in following error:

```
(Reading database ... 2602 files and directories currently installed.)
Preparing to unpack vscode-amd64.deb ...
Unpacking visual-studio-code (1.2.1-1465908640) over (1.2.1-1465908640) ...
dpkg: dependency problems prevent configuration of visual-studio-code:
 visual-studio-code depends on git; however:
  Package git is not installed.

dpkg: error processing package visual-studio-code (--install):
 dependency problems - leaving unconfigured
Errors were encountered while processing:
 visual-studio-code
```

I know I have git installed, so I tried `which git` and it returns `/usr/bin/git` then I thought maybe it is looking for something else, so I did a re-install of `git` by executing `sudo pacman -Syu` and it re installed my git but there was no version change as I had updated git already.

Then I try to execute `sudo dpkg -i vscode-amd64.deb` then I get the same error message

Steps to Reproduce:
1. execute `sudo dpkg -i vscode-amd64.deb`

data.title: API Request: Move Tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-Insiders
- OS Version: OSX

Per https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6605 , we already exposed APIs to move active editors across groups. And we do support drag and drop tabs so I'm thinking can we expose tabs moving functionalities as API, then people can move tabs by commands.

This will benefit Vim extensions as moving tabs is a useful often-used command. For now only the last four commands can be implemented with existing APIs.

```
:tabs         list all tabs including their displayed windows
:tabm 0       move current tab to first
:tabm         move current tab to last
:tabm {i}     move current tab to position i+1

:tabn         go to next tab
:tabp         go to previous tab
:tabfirst     go to first tab
:tablast      go to last tab

```

@bpasero @kieferrm

data.title: getWordRangeAtPosition does not respect word separator settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OX X El Capitan 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Edit user preferences to set "editor.wordSeparators": " ()\"':,;~@#$%^&{}[]`"
2. Call getWordRangeAtPosition with a position inside a string like "clojure.test".
   Result: Returned range only contains "clojure" or "test" depending on chosen position.
   Expected result: Returned range contains entire string "clojure.test".

I am almost done, I need to tweak the whitespace only lines and empty lines rendering. It sits behind a "hidden" `editor.indentGuides` option. I hope I squeeze it in on ~~Tuesday~~ Wednesday ;) :)

data.title: Font-weight is now numerically light. Fixes #6759
data.body:
Also fixes #6792.

Some fonts like Helvetica Neue and San Fransisco do not match the font-family's weight for italics unless you explicitly define `font-weight` to numerically be light as well.  This fixes that.

You'll notice a **change on Windows** as a result of this, because Segoe UI was being used and not Segoe UI Light.  This change causes Segoe UI Light to appear.  (I'm actually not sure why were using a light font on Mac but not on Windows—this sort of standardizes it as a side effect). Let me know your thoughts on this.  This does not affect Ubuntu (even though it should in theory).

This is what Windows would look like
![screen shot 2016-06-27 at 5 41 39 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11839736/16400261/95e508f6-3c8e-11e6-91f0-a9fb227f4cd0.png)

data.title: Multiline find
data.body:
You can test in any OS
- [x] any os - @Tyriar 
- [x] any os - @dbaeumer 

If you turn on the regex checkbox in the find widget, you can now search for `\r` or `\n`. Please check cases with different end of line sequences (CRLF vs LF). Please check find prev, find next, replace next, replace all, etc individually (they point to different implementations).

It is unclear to me what to do with the find in selection, I have a feeling it is now too eagerly activating. Please let me know in issues how you feel about it.

data.title: Standalone Editor
data.body:
We haven't done a cross-browser **exploratory** feature check for the standalone editor in quite some time.

You can use https://microsoft.github.io/monaco-editor/index.html or `npm install monaco-editor` and set up your own test pages. Any form of feedback is welcome, including on the `monaco-editor` README, on the documentation site, etc. PRs are even better! :)

Here is the list of browsers we support, I am not sure how many testers would need to be assigned:
- [x] IE 9 - @isidorn 
- [x] IE 10 - @isidorn
- [x] IE 11 - @isidorn
- [x] Edge - @isidorn
- [x] Chrome - @jrieken 
- [x] Firefox - @gregvanl 
- [x] Safari - @sandy081 
- [x] Opera - @jrieken

data.title: Opening a link in editor should focus opened browser & support filesystem paths

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (41f53d27a8cb477130f84116c78f43ddacbaf24b, 2016-06-27T05:07:29.758Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14366

Using the links generated for URLs could be improved:
- When Ctrl+Clicking on a link, please focus the opened browser (when the link opens in Edge, Edge flashes orange but is not brought into focus). This is true whether opening in an existing browser window or opening a new one.
- Please support file system paths and UNC paths (starting with \\) being auto-linked in VS Code (similar to email clients like Outlook auto-detecting such links). Ctrl+Click on such a link would open up the path in the OS's file browser on the computer. It wouldn't be perfect for systems like Windows which tend to put spaces in paths, but developers even on Windows often enough choose paths without spaces and VS Code is mainly an editor for developers so I think it would be good enough to simply treat a space as a delimiter for the link.

data.title: Test: Integrated Terminal (June)
data.body:
Test plan for June's improvements made to the integrated terminal (#143 ). This test plan will take a fair bit of time to get through.
#### Operating Systems
- [x] Windows - @chrmarti
- [x] Mac @isidorn 
- [x] Linux - @kieferrm
#### What's new?

_A lot_ of stuff changed in the terminal, many bugs were fixed, some big features landed like multiple terminals and the ability to consistently copy and paste (currently bound to <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>ins</kbd> to copy, <kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>ins</kbd> to paste), the underlying library that powers the terminal was swapped out for a more mature one ([xterm.js](https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js)) and there was a big refactor to support all these changes. CJK character width was also fixed so they should no longer have random sizing and/or wrap and break the row count of the terminal.

A full list of the changes can be seen [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3Aintegrated-terminal+milestone%3A%22June+2016%22+is%3Aclosed).
#### What to test?

Here is a mostly complete list of test cases around features that were added, fixed or impacted greatly by the refactor and xterm.js adoption:
- Adding multiple terminals (<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+`backtick`, removing various indexes (first, last, middle)
- Using a non-standard shell
- Using `exit` to kill the shell
- Using copy <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>ins</kbd> and paste <kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>ins</kbd>
- Using middle click to paste selection on Linux
- Try building and running vscode through the integrated terminal (`./scripts/code.sh`)
- CJK and general unicode characters can be input and viewed in the terminal. note that you cannot use an IME currently sourcelair/xterm.js#124 (the varying height of unicode characters is a known issue #8219)
- Resizing:
  - Vertically & horizontally
  - With and without a program running
  - With little output
- Scrolling:
  - <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+arrow (or mac equivalent)
  - <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+page up/down (or mac equivalent)
  - Mouse or trackpad (reports of trackpad scroll not working on mac #7817)
- Using the new settings (they should apply without needing a window reload):
  - Add args when spawning a new shell: `terminal.integrated.shellArgs.<platform>`
  - Change font family: `terminal.integrated.fontSize`
  - Change line height: `terminal.integrated.lineHeight`
- Using the new commands:
  - `workbench.action.terminal.focus`
  - `workbench.action.terminal.focusNext`
  - `workbench.action.terminal.focusPrevious`
  - `workbench.action.terminal.kill`
  - Disable cursor blinking: `editor.cursorBlinking`
  - Run the editor selection in the terminal: `workbench.action.terminal.runSelectedText`
- Adjusting font size and line height
- Text foreground and background color is inverted on selection like in `gnome-terminal`
- The new "hollow" cursor when the terminal does not have focus
- Ensure vim no longer overrides the terminal color set #6457

data.title: Lines containing unicode characters in integrated terminal differ in height

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: See https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/149, the fix will probably be added to the custom `style` element. The main thing to consider is how to allow line height customization and get the lines aligned correctly at the same time.

data.title: refactored serviceCollection
data.body: I think that this form of ServiceCollection class is easier to understand.

data.title: Unsaved file warning for deleted files inside a deleted folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: win server 2012 R2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a new folder and create a file inside it.
2. add some content to the new file and save
3. add more content to the file and do **NOT** save
4. one unsaved file should be marked in VSCode Open Editors section in explorer tab
5. Right click on the newly created folder and delete the folder

**Actual**:  Open editors section still shows "1 unsaved" label while that file is deleted with folder delete.
It's kind of confusing what the unsaved file is and there is no way to ignore or save it in the UI unless closing the VSCode.

**Expected**: If I'm deleting a folder it means I don't care about the files inside that folder whether they are saved or not. Therefore, VSCode should ignore all unsaved files inside the deleted folder.

data.title: No syntax highlighting for Unity
data.body:
This may have to be implemented in the future, once you guys have further unity support, but basically no matter which theme I use, Unity specific variables / types / classes do not have syntax highlighting.
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open unity project with VS Code
2. Use some unity specific variables / types / classes (e.g Camera, Vector3, etc..)
3. Observe no syntax highlighting

data.title: Extensions UI
data.body:
- [x] win - @alexandrudima 
- [x] mac - @weinand 
- [x] linux - @Tyriar 

We have introduced a new viewlet to improve the extensions management scenario. All the old extension management funcitonality is preserved. Verify:
- you can browse extensions from the marketplace
- you can install / uninstall an extension
- you get notified that there is an extension upgrade
- you get extenion recommendations based on your project
- clicking on an extension shows the extension description
- extension list is synchronized accross multiple vscode instances

Note: this feature has been developed by @joaomoreno however since he is on vacation this week assign all issues to @isidorn

data.title: Markdown highlighting issue in nested lists
data.body:
1. create a markdown file with the following content

```
* xxx
    * xxx
    * `xx.xx` `yy.yy`
```

-> `yy.yy` has the wrong color
